I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment  of  $75  million  or  CNY  equivalent  in  the  Bank  of  China  Ltd.  (BOC),  a  state-owned 
commercial bank (SOCB) in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), as a key step in the financial 
reform of the PRC banking sector.    
 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Industry Background and Sector Reform 

1. 

Overview of PRC Financial System and State-Owned Commercial Banks 

 
2. 
Banks clearly dominate the PRC’s financial system and at present account for 54% of the 
total assets of all financial institutions in the PRC.1 In 2005, the PRC’s banking system comprises 
four nationwide SOCBs, 12 nationwide joint-stock commercial banks, 112 city commercial banks, 
8  rural  commercial  banks,  about  2,000  urban  credit  cooperatives,  and about  28,000  rural  credit 
cooperatives.2 Assets of these financial institutions have grown at a compounded annual growth 
rate (CAGR) of 13% since 2000 and stood at $3.8 trillion at the end of 2004, about the same as 
the assets of the United Kingdom’s financial sector (Figure 1).

The  SOCBs  play  a  major  role  in  the  allocation  of  funds  throughout  the  economy  as  well  as 
serving as an important gauge of the overall health of the financial system.  
 
B. 
 
5. 
The PRC banking sector was originally regulated by the People’s Bank of China (PBOC). 
Since 1998, responsibilities have been divided between PBOC and the China Banking Regulatory 
Commission  (CBRC).  PBOC,  guided  by  the  State  Council,  is  responsible  for  formulating  and 
implementing monetary policy and for enacting safeguards to ensure financial stability. CBRC is 
the main regulator of the banking sector and its responsibilities include formulating and enforcing 
the supervisory rules and regulations governing bank institutions. 

Financial Sector Reforms  

 
6. 
The  PRC  regulators  place  numerous  restrictions  on  permissible  products,  services,  and 
activities  of  domestic  and  foreign  banks.  For  example,  there  are  still  restrictions  on  commercial 
banks  offering  fee-based  products.  Interest  rates  on  loans  and  deposits  offered  by  commercial 
banks are still subject to PBOC regulations even after recent reform measures that gave banks 
more  latitude  in  setting such  interest  rates.  On  the  other  hand,  the  PRC  Government  has  been 
gradually reforming the banking sector by allowing new product offerings and expanding the limits 
within  which  commercial  banks  may  set  their  CNY  lending  rates.  In  particular,  on  29 October 
2004,  the  PBOC  removed  the  upper  limit  for  CNY  lending  rates  (other  than  rates  on  mortgage 
loans  to  individuals)  charged  by  financial  institutions,  excluding  credit  cooperatives,  while 
retaining the lower limit for such rates. Since that date, all deposit-taking institutions have been 
permitted  to  decrease  (but  not  increase)  CNY  deposit  rates  to  below  the  corresponding  PBOC 
benchmark rates. These changes give banks more freedom to develop products to meet market 
needs and to offer more flexibility in determining pricing of their products. 
 
Despite  focused  monetary  and  financial  sector  reforms,3  the  PRC  financial  sector  does 
7. 
not  yet  meet  the  needs  of  a  market  economy.  Indirect  monetary  policy  instruments  (e.g.,  open 
market  operations)  are  not  fully  developed  and  interest  rate  policy  remains  inflexible. 4  The 
regulatory and supervisory framework for banks and nonbank financial institutions remains weak. 
Despite  substantial  progress,  the  capital  markets  are  still  underdeveloped  and  have  not  been 
adequately regulated and supervised. 5  
 
A developed financial system mobilizes investments, manages risks, and reduces the cost

9. 
To  address  these  problems,  the  PRC  is  undertaking  a  historic  transformation  of  its 
banking and financial sector. The three central pillars of this transformation are: (i) reducing NPLs, 
particularly in the SOCBs;6 (ii) restructuring the SOCBs to make them more commercially viable 
and to avoid new NPLs; and (iii) promoting a stronger credit culture and competitiveness in the 
banking  and  financial  sector  as  a  whole  to  prepare  for  market  shifts,  such  as  interest  rate 
liberalization  and  local  currency  operations  by  foreign  banks.  The  success  of  these  interlinked 
measures  will  determine  the  ability  of  the  PRC  to  generate  the  positive  and  sustainable  credit 
expansion needed to fuel the growing economy.  
 

1. 

World Trade Organization Accession and Competition from Foreign Banks 

 
10. 
The  PRC’s  accession  to  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  further  emphasizes  the 
urgency of SOE and financial sector reform, especially with respect to the four SOCBs. Given that 
WTO entry effectively opens the PRC’s financial sector to foreign participants, the PRC’s financial 
institutions will face increasing competition and challenges.  
 
11. 
In an attempt to penetrate the growing and lucrative PRC banking market, foreign financial 
institutions  have  invested  in  several  PRC  banks  over  the  past  few  years.  Although  the  pace  of 
these  investments  has  increased,  it  is  worth  noting  that  so  far  they  have  been  limited  to 
investments in city banks and joint-stock banks.7 No foreign investment in any of the SOCBs has 
yet reached financial closure.  

 
2. 

SOCB Restructuring and Corporatization 

 
12. 
Given  the  dominant  role  that  the  four  SOCBs  have  in  the  overall  PRC  financial  system, 
the  Government  can  not  afford  to  put  the  survival  of  the  four  SOCBs  at  risk.  Therefore,  in  an 
attempt  to  prepare  for  future  competition  from  foreign  banks  and  to  respond  to  the  other 
challenges  faced  by  the  four  banks,  the  Government  has  increased  its  support  for  shareholder 
reform. It selected BOC as one of two SOCBs to be restructured into joint stock companies 8 and 
to undergo major corporate restructuring. 
 
C. 
 

Trends in the PRC Banking Industry 

1.

average annual growth of 9.4%. Its foreign trade rose during the same period from $20 billion to 
$1.2 trillion, surpassing that of Japan. The PRC is currently the sixth largest economy in the world 
and its GDP growth continues to outpace those of other countries. If the average GDP growth of

2. 

Corporate Lending and Growing Demand for Retail Banking Products 

 
Corporate banking will remain the primary focus of the PRC banking industry in the near 
16. 
to midterm future, because of the sheer demand and growth potential. PRC corporations are the 
growth  engine  of  the  country’s  economic  development.  In  the  past,  a  large  majority  of  loans  by 
PRC  financial  institutions  have  been  made  to  SOEs,  a  trend  which  will  change  as  financial 
reforms  continue.  In  addition,  newly  founded  privately-owned  corporations  are  becoming 
increasingly important borrowers. 
 

  

5 

17. 
As the PRC banking industry has been reformed, banking institutions have been allowed 
to offer consumer lending products. Rising incomes are likely to foster growing consumer demand 
for banking products and services. It is anticipated that retail banking will continue to grow, with 
increasing demands for mortgages and other consumer loans. According to the National Bureau 
of  Statistics,  consumer  loans  in  the  PRC  totaled  CNY2.0  trillion  in  2004,  representing  10.5%  of 
total loans and 14.6% of GDP, and grew at a compound annual growth rate of 36.5% from 2002 
to 2004. 
 
18.  Mortgage  loans  represented  the  majority  of  overall  consumer  loans  in  2003,  and  were 
fueled  by  the  Government’s  efforts  to  reform  the  housing  system,  under  which  employees  of 
state-owned  enterprises  previously  received  free  or  subsidized  housing.  Mortgage  loans  have 
grown  rapidly  from  CNY609.9  billion  in  2001  to  over  CNY1.2  trillion  in  2003,  according  to  the 
Ministry of Construction. 
 
19. 
The  vast  majority  of  bank  cards  in  the  PRC  are  debit  cards.  There  are  approximately 
517,000 credit and points-of-sale and 67,000 automated teller machines (ATMs) in the PRC. The 
credit  card  market  has  so  far  been  limited  for  a  variety  of  reasons,  including  the  limited 
acceptance  of  cards  by  merchants,  the  underdevelopment  of  a  national  payment  infrastructure, 
and  the  absence  of  a  nationwide  consumer  credit  information  system.  According  to  the  PRC 
Unionpay,  an  electronic  interbank  information  exchange  and  transaction  network,  at  the  end  of 
2004, 815 million banking cards had been issued in the PRC, only 11 million of which were credit 
cards.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

The Investee Company 

 
A. 
 
20. 
Established in  1921,  BOC  is  the  second  largest of  the  PRC’s  four  SOCBs  as  ranked  by 
total  assets.  After  the  founding  of  the  PRC  in  1949,  BOC  was  restructured  to  specialize  in 
international  trade  finance.  At  the  same  time,  its  operations  were  merged  into  the  new  central 
bank,  PBOC.  In  1979,  at  the  onset  of  PRC’s  economic  reforms,  BOC  was  separated  from  the 
PBOC and became the PRC’s designated foreign exchange bank. Today, traditional commercial 
banking  constitutes  the  majority  of  BOC’s  business,  which  comprises  corporate  banking,  retail 
banking,  and  banking  with  financial  institutions.  In  line  with  the  developing  trends  in  the 
international  financial  industry,  BOC  has  strengthened  its  commercial  banking  business  while 
expanding its investment banking and insurance activities.  
 
21. 
BOC  operates  11,307  domestic  branches  and  603  overseas  branches,  and  has 
subsidiaries in 27 countries and regions around the world. At the end of 2003, it had more than 
188,000 staff. Domestic lending represents about three quarters of its gross loans and over 80% 
of  domestic  loans  are  corporate  loans  (about  half  of  which  are  to  SOEs).  BOC  also  dominates 
foreign exchange services and accounts for about 50% of PRC’s foreign currency deposit market.  
 
22.

presence in Hong Kong, China, and in Macau, China. Its subsidiary, Bank of China (Hong Kong) 
Limited (BOCHK), is the second largest banking group in Hong Kong, China, with approximately

Development Impact and Effectiveness 

 
The  proposed  investment  will  promote  best  credit  and  governance  practices.  BOC’s

A. 

Establishment, Licensing and Regulation of Banks in the PRC 

 
The  People’s  Republic  of  China’s  (PRC’s)  central  bank,  the  People’s  Bank  of  China 
1. 
(PBOC),  was  formerly  also  the  PRC’s  banking  industry  regulator.  In  April  2003,  the  State 
Council  established  the  China  Banking  Regulatory  Commission  (CBRC,  and  together  with 
PBOC,  referred  to  as  the  Regulator),  to  take  over  most  of  the  banking  supervisory  functions 
from  PBOC.  After  these  reforms,  CBRC  became  the  primary  banking  industry  regulator, 
responsible  for  the  supervision  and  administration  of  all  banks  in  the  PRC  and  their  business 
activities.  PBOC  retained  certain  supervisory  functions,  and  became  primarily  responsible  for 
formulating and implementing monetary policy as the PRC’s central bank. 
 
2. 
Key laws applicable to banks in the PRC include the Commercial Bank Law, Company 
Law, PBOC Law, and Law on the Supervision and Administration of Banking Business. In the 
course of implementing these laws, the Regulator has issued various regulations, circulars, and 
notices covering specific issues. 
 
3. 
According  to  the  Commercial  Bank  Law,  the  establishment  of  commercial  banks  and 
their branches is subject to examination and approval by the Regulator. The minimum amount 
of registered capital for the establishment of a nation wide commercial bank is CNY1 billion and 
the registered capital should be paid up in full. When establishing a branch, commercial banks 
should allocate appropriate amounts of working capital to the branch in the light of the proposed 
scale  of  operations  of  the  branch.  The  total  working  capital  allocated  to  the  branches  of  a 
commercial bank should not exceed 60% of the total capital of the head office.
